ygData.subject: 378 days later...
ygData.msgSnippet: Good grief, it s been just over a year since I last posted here. It s probably not unfair to say that life got in the way (two job changes, builders ripping

Good grief, it's been just over a year since I last posted here. It's
proba=
bly not unfair to say that life got in the way (two job changes,
builders r=
ipping house apart, kids being kids, the usual stuff).

But that's neither =
important nor relevant right now.

Those with elephantine memories may reca=
ll my on-off obsession with
beating the bookies in the fixed-odds football =
betting market through
the cunning application of AI. Last week I finally f=
ound myself in the
blissful position of having a dual-CPU work machine with=
 Visual Studio
.NET 2005 installed, something that just screamed for a reop=
ening of
my NEAT files.

So far, I've downloaded Colin's latest SharpNEAT s=
ource, upgraded it
to .NET 2.0 (largely painless) and developed an experime=
nt that uses
my venerable result and odds files. I'll describe the approach=
 taken
anon, but I thought I'd share some observations:

SharpNEAT: I hadn'=
t realised until I started coding against it what a
really nice job this is=
. I mean, I knew it was good, but the ease of
incorporating a model, once I=
 finally got around to it, was still a
surprise. I'd guess it took about 8 =
hours' effort to get the thing
running from the end of the download.

Part =
of the exercise was to get myself back up to speed in the C#
stakes: I hadn=
't written any code in .NET for about 18 months. I
replaced the progress fo=
rm graph controls with ZedGraph (from
SourceForge) ones as an exercise.

Ne=
twork evolution. I speculated last year on the value of starting
with a spa=
rsely-connected network (or one with no connections at all).
I'm extremely =
happy with the limited practical experience I've had
with this approach: th=
e early generations, while fairly stupid,
evaluate at a tremendous rate, so=
 complexities that allow some
reasonable attempt at the problem are quickly=
 reached. Playing with
species numbers via the compatibility threshold is, =
I'm sure, going to
be instructive once I've worked out what I think it's te=
aching me!

Architecture. Despite the complete lack of activity on the codi=
ng
front, I've continued to evolve my thinking on this. What I decided to
d=
o for this first cut was to evolve a model that would form its own
opinions=
 about the relative strengths of teams. I therefore decided to
add some out=
puts to the networks and save them against the team(s)
involved inthe match=
 being evaluated. These saved outputs would then
form part of the input for=
 the next match that involved that team. I
hoped that the more successful n=
etworks would learn to calculate a set
of "ratings" for each team. Since ra=
tings need to change with results,
I also added the team's most recent resu=
lt (epxressed as a goal
difference) and the network's most recent predictio=
n to the inputs. I
have in the past expressed a liking for the idea of a "c=
onfidence"
value as a separate output, so I put one of those in too...

The=
 inputs currently look like this:

Home team block:
    Last result, last p=
redicted win chance & confidence
    "memory block" (4 numbers, four becaus=
e it seemed like a nice number)
Away team block:
     As above
A value to i=
ndicate the division in which the match takes place, to
give the network a =
chance to arrive at a sensible number for
newly-promoted teams

The network=
 is then given a chance to relax over multiple steps (takes
about 4 or 5 ty=
pically - those that fail to converge within 10 steps
are penalised)

Outpu=
ts currently look like this:
Home win, Away win and Draw probabilities & co=
nfidence factors (6 outputs)
Home team "memory block" (4)
Away team "memory=
 block" (4)

Each network evaluation consists of a "calibration" period, co=
nsisting
of eight years of results being pushed through to develop the mode=
l's
"memory", then a further four seasons for which odds are available are
=
run through. Networks are, by and large, assigned a fitness according
to th=
e profit they make.

Results to date: The best network I've evolved so far =
managed to take
an initial stake of 1,000 and, subject to staking limits of=
 a 50
maximum, generate a profit of about 10,000. I'm rather pleased with
t=
hat :-) The champion networks tend to have very few hidden nodes (one
to fo=
ur) but a forest of interconnections on the output layer,
probably somethin=
g that stems from "relaxing" over multiple steps.

Questions to be answered=
:
1. Is the best network overfitting/memorizing the profitable bets?
Quite =
possibly - I need to source some more recent data for testing.
2. How robus=
t is the calibration/memory aspect? Would the network
arrive at the same re=
sult if, say, the first seasons' data were excluded?
3. Will I continue to =
have time to build a front end for the "final
solution" network and have it=
 ready to test with real money next
season? (I'm prepared to bankroll a prm=
ising candidate to the tune of
100 quid or so, for the entertainment if not=
hing else).

Well, I came back with a monster. If you've reached the end, y=
ou have
my congratulations (and sympathy for the loss of time it's caused).=

I'd welcome any comments, suggestions, or other feedback.

It's nice to be=
 back.

Mike
